column1: It is natural to believe in great men. If the companions of our childhood should turn out to be heroes
column3: it would not surprise us. All mythology opens with demigods
column4: and the circumstance is high and poetic; that is
column5: their genius is paramount. In the legends of the Gautama
column6: the first men ate the earth
column7: and found it deliciously sweet.Nature seems to exist for the excellent. The world is upheld by the veracity of good men: they make the earth wholesome. They who lived with them found life glad and nutritious. Life is sweet and tolerable only in our belief in such society; and actually
column9: we manage to live with superiors. We call our children and our lands by their names. Their names are wrought into the verbs of language
column10: their works and effigies are in our houses
column11: and every circumstance of the day recalls an anecdote of them.
